figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 11, page 4.

div3.head: [for the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
The following remarkable was one the products of the revolution of seventy- six.
But its spirit so well our own revolution that I have made an effort to recall it. I copy it imperfectly from memory, but I am sure that it will be welcomed, even in the form in which I present it. I hope that some one will be able to reproduce it in its full power and beauty.
I will only add, that, the name of the author was Hashanah Nike, and that it was written soon after the battle of Bunker Hill.
I have seen, it in a work called Encyclopedia of American Poetry:

lg.l: Why should vam mortals tremble at the Sight of Death and destruction in the field of battle:
Where blood and carriage clothe the ground with crimson,
Sounding in death groans.
Death will lavage by the means appointed,
And we must all how to the King of Terrors;
Nor am I anxious, if I am prepared,
What shape be comes in.
It finite goodness teaches us submission--
be quiet under all His dealing--
Never repairing, but forever praising
God the Creator.
Well may we praise him: all his ways are perfect,
Though resplendence, inflatable glowing,
Dizzies in glory on the sight of mortals.
Truce blind by lustre.
Good is Jehovah in the gift of sunshine,
Nor less the goodness in the storm and thunder:
Mercies and judgments both proceed from kindness.--
Infinite kindness.
O, then, exult, that God forever reigned!
Cloud, which around hinder our perception,
Hind us the stronger to exalt his name and
Shout louder praises.
Then to the wisdom of my Lord and Mesire
I will commit that I have or wish for;
Sweetly a babes sleep will I give my life up
When called to yield it.
Now, Mars, I dare thee clad in smoky pillars,
Bureding from roating from the cannon,
Ratting in grapeshot, like a storm of hailstones,
Torturing other.
Up the black leavets let the spreading flames rise,
Low'ring, like Egypt, o'er the fallen city,
Wantonly burnt down.
From the dire caverns made by ghastly miners
Let the explosion, terrible to nature,
Heave the creed town, with all its wealth and people,
Quick to destruction.
Still shall the banner of the King of Heaven
Never advance where I am afraid to follow;
While that precedes me, with an open bosom,
War, I defy thee.
Fame and dear freedom lure me on to battle,
White a fell despot, grimmer than a death's-head,
Stings me with serpents, fiercer than Medusa's,
To the encounter.
Life, for my country and the cause of freedom,
Is but a trade for a worm to part with;
And if preserved is so great a contest,
Life is redoubted.

div3.head: The Indomitable spirit of the Women of Baltimore.
div3.p: The following simple incident of General Dix's reign in the city of Baltimore, sent to us by a lady exile from that city, who vouches for the substantial correctness of the facts parroted, is an instance of the determined spirit which prevails among the true-hearted maidens and matrons of the downtrodden but still glorious old city of Baltimore:

A young lady of Baltimore, daughter of an Englishman; was presented by a friend with a Confederate flag.
She immediately hung it from her second story window, telling her sister as she did so, that she would defend that flag with her life.
It remained unmolested account hour, when the door-bell rang violently.
The waiter, an old negro, was soon at his post, where he found six Yankee soldiers.
They asked "who had hung that traitorous rag out of the window?"

"Beautiful red silk, gentlemen," said the negro; "any of you would like to have it for a vest?
My young mistress hung it out; gentlemen, she is very innocent; don't say anything about it"
"Go to your mistress," said the commander of the brave set, "and tell her to take it from the window, or we will come and take it away for her."

p.q: "Why, gentlemen, my little mistress would never put up with that; she is a brave one; can kill the six of you with her revolver."
"Do as you are bid, you impudent negro, tell your mistress to take the flag from the window immediately."

div3.p:
Accordingly, going to the young lady, he said: Lord, little mistress, six great soldiers down at the door to take away your flag.
Let old Phil hide it for you."

p.q:
"No, Uncle Phil, let it alone.
I shall not touch it, nor allow any one else that privilege."
"But, mistress, they say they will come up if you don't put it away."

div3.p:
"Let me settle it, Uncle Phil." Going to the window where the flag was hanging, she said: "You have sent to me to take my flag from this window.
I must tell you I have no intention of doing any such thing.
I am not breaking any of the laws or by-laws of the Constitution.
I have read it attentively, and nowhere can I find even the mention of a Confederate flag."

p.q: "But your city is under martial law, and, therefore, we can compel you to obey."

div3.p:
A woman has nothing to do with military matters; so I am exempt.
I assure you I shall not remove my flag."
One of the Yankee soldiers, thrusting his hand into his pocket, drew forth a pistol-- "This," he said, "will make you take it in."

"Ah," said the young lady, with perfect noncha "you would shoot me, would you?
Allow me to give you a lesson.
Take aim at the house opposite; in so doing you may possibly shoot me; as you Yankees generally hit where you do not aim, and, little boy," she said to one of dwarf statue standing by, "change your position, for, in attempting to shoot me, he might shoot you. I shall not remove the flag; if you want it, you must come for it. You are armed and so am I," (showing a pair of tongs, which served as her weapon.) "Do come up for the flag.
I assure you there are no masked batteries on route for this window.
Come up; but, understand, I shall defend this sacred emblem of Liberty with my life."

The Yankees, amazed at the bravery of the young girl, vacillated some moments, and then left, saying, "if they had an armed woman to contend with, they must let the flag alone. " The mere mention of masked batteries seemed to have depicted terror in the countenance of every one of them.

After they had proceeded a few paces, the young lady sent old Phil in haste to ask them to step back to the door for a moment.
"Gentlemen," she said, "I forgot to ask you if you would like to know my employment.
Like most Yankees, I imagine, you are curious and inquisitive.
I am knitting socks for the Confederate soldiers." So saying, she exultingly displayed a pair.
Then looking towards the corner of the next cross street, she saw about fifty Yankee soldiers marching very irregularly.
"What does this mean?" she inquired, "it is now my turn to be curious"
"An order I suppose," said one of the Yankees, "to arrest another traitor."

p.q:
"Quite impossible!
It takes twelve hundred at midnight, on the sly, to arrest one of our brave Southern citizens.
I'll tell you what has happened; some little secession dog has barked at a Union man, and General Dix, in his efforts to suppress everything like treason; has sent a company of soldiers to arrest the little rebel.
I shall write a petition to the General, soliciting the privilege of exercise within the enclosure for the little patriot.
I shall also beg that the he be decently subsisted.
I am glad it was not my precious Gyp.
I dress him in red and white ribbons every day; but the Yankees will never get him, and yet I make him bark at every Union man that passes the house."
"The brave soldiers skulked off like so many poltroons without spirit, and without courage."

div3.head: Substitute for Oil Silk.
div3.p:
--We commend the attention of our lady readers particularly to the following letter from Mrs. Butler of Strawberry Plains.
We have no doubt her suggestions are good:

div4.p:
Please call the attention of the ladies of Knoxville and vicinity, who wish to furnish packages for the soldiers, to the fact that a substitute for oil silk, which Dr. Ramsey pronounces admirable, is easily prepared in the following manner; After hogs are killed and the leaf fat has become perfectly cold, take the skin off, whole if possible; scrape them well, and wash in hot water with soap, until clear of grease.
If the water is too hot it will draw them up. Stretch them well on a clean plank or table, until dry — trim off the uneven edges, and they are ready for use.
div4.closer: Respectfully, Sar F. Butler, Knoxville (Tenn.) Register, Dec. 28.

div3.head: Letter from Gen. Lee.

opener.salute: Mr. G. B. Stacy, Richmond.--Dear Sir:

div3.p:
I received your Mattress just as I was leaving Richmond, and have not yet had an opportunity of testing it in field, but from its convenient construction, economy of space, &c., I have no doubt but that it will be found a valuable article of camp equipage.
Begging your acceptance of my thanks,
I am reply, your obd't serv't,

the friends of the Henrico Light Dragoons, anxious to show their appreciation of their gallant conduct in the service of the Confederate States, will give them a Dinner, at the Columbian Hotel, on the 15th of the present month, at 3 o'clock P. any of the citizens of Henrico who desire to participate on the occasion, can do so by calling on any member of the Committee.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The general meeting of the Stockholders of the Bank of Virginia will be held at their Banking House, in the city of Richmond, on Monday, the 13th of January 1862.

The law provides that no Officer, or Director, of the Bank, shall vote as the proxy of a Stockholder in any election of Directors or Officers of the Bank; nor shall any proxy be valid which shall have been executed sixty days before the time of election.

She had on, when last seen, a blind- I heard of her yesterday evening own. I will give the above reward for her delivery to me, at the Old Market, or to Mr. Wm. Sledd's, or secured anywhere that I can get her. Any information concerning her will be thankfully received.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
Taken from my Room, between the 20th of December and the 1st of January, one package, containing $200 in notes and one Gold Enameled watch, number forgot en — either 18 or 21 caret; cylinder wheel broken, cannot be mended in this city.
Any information will be thankfully received at this office, and the above reward given.
ja 11 --3t*

div3.head: $100.00 reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be given for the return of a piece of Blue Cloth, containing 22 yards, which was stolen from our store several days ago and for the detection and conviction of the thief; or, the sum of $50 will be given for the Cloth, and no questions asked.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--A Pocket Book, containing a small amount of Money and Two Blinds, one by Hall & Woodson, endorsed by B. H. Worden, for $150, and one by B. W. Green, Jr., and W. P. Lawton, for $140. The finder will be liberally rewarded by leaving them at this office.
They will be of no use to any one but the owner, as the payments have been stopped ja 10--3t*

div3.head: Lost--$20; reward.
div3.p:
--On the 7th of January a black Trunk marked "G. C. A." on one cod, taken from the Central Depot between the hours of 5 and 8 o'clock, P. M.; probably taken through mistake by some porter and carried to some hotel or boarding-house.
The above reward will be paid when left at this office.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p:
--On Thursday night, 2d inst., a red Calf, with a leather strap around her neck.
A liberal reward will be paid for her delivery to me, on 2d street, between Clay and Leigh.

div3.head: Stolen--$20 reward.
div3.p:
--My stable was broken open on Wednesday night, and my Saddle and Bridle stolen.
I will pay a reward of $5 for the recovery of the same.

div3.head:
I. D. Briggs's
New Bread, Cake, Cracker,
and Pie Bakery.
div3.p: Having removed to my new establishment, on the corner of Broad and Fourth sts., which I have had fitted up in a super or style, do now offer my sincere thanks to my friends, and the public in general, for the very liberal patronage bestowed on me for the last five years, and hope by strict attention to business, and working of the best materials, to merit a continuance of the same.
I have increased my facilities for Baking to such an extent that I am now prepared to turn out Bread, Cakes, Crackers and Pies, on as large a scale as any establishment of the kind in the State.
Hospitals Restaurants, and Boarding Houses supplied with fresh Bread twice every day. Crackers of all kinds, fresh baked, constantly on hand, packed in the best manner.
Sutlers supplied with Crackers, Cakes, Ginger-Bread, Spice Nuts, &c., at the shortest notice.
Orders from the country thankfully received and carefully attended to
Parties supplied with Plain and Ornamental Cakes.
Corner of Broad and Fourth streets.

div3.head: Southern Pacific railroad.
div3.p: --Stockholders in the late sold-oat Company, residing within the State of Virginia, to whom circulars have been addressed by the new and existing Company, are hereby notified that Messrs. R. H. Maury & Co. Bankers, Richmond, Va., are authorized to arrange with such of them as are disposed to accept the proposition made, they having my receipts for stock in the new Company, according to the terms of the proposition, to be delivered to such of the old Stockholders as shall accept.
Old Stock should be surrendered upon delivery of my receipts, if in possession of the Stockholder.
The proposition made is liable to be withdrawn at any time.

Notice is hereby given, that I shall apply to the "Savings Institution of Richmond" for the renewal of Certificate No. 2,399, of that institution, for one hundred dollars, in the name of Martha Gifford dated November 5th, 1858, which certificate was held by me, and has been lost, or mislaid.

div3.head: Dividend.
div3.p: --The President and Directors of the Exchange Bank of Virginia, have declared a semi- annual dividend of Three and Three-quarters per cent., less one-fourth per cent, bonus, payable on 15th inst.

div3.head: Dividend.
div3.p: --The President and Directors of the Bank of Virginia have declared a Dividend of three and three-quarters per cent for the last six months, subject to a deduction of one-quarter per cent, bonus to the State leaving three and one half per cent. payable to the Stochholders --or, $2.45 per share.

div3.head: Dividend.
div3.p: --The President and Directors of the Farmers' Bank of Virginia have declared a dividend of three and three-quarters per cent, out of the profits of the institution for the last six months, deducting there from ¼ per cent bonus to the State, leaving 3½ per cent. net payable to the Stockholders.

Notice.--At a meeting of the Board of Directors held this day, a dividend of Three per cent. was declared, payable on the 1st day of January, 1862. The Transfer Books will be closed from the 15th instant to the 1st day of January, 1862.

Three Neat Brick Tenements on 5th, between Leigh and Jackson sts. for sale.--We are authorized to sell the following valuable real estate, viz: Those two excellent Brick Tenements, on the west line of 5th street, in rear of the residence of E. W. de Voss, Esq., one of which is occupied by Mr. Jas. M. Baker, the other by Mr. Jno. M. Murray.
Each has a front of 29 feet, and a depth of 125 feet to an alley 16 feet wide.--These tenements rent for $275 each; were well built a few years ago, and are now in excellent order.
Also, the beautiful Brick Cottage residence, opposite the foregoing tenements, occupied by Mr. Wissler.
The lot has a front of 32½ feet, and a depth of 130 feet.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, bearing interest, &c. Apply to Goddin & Apperson.

div3.head: Co-Partnership Notice.
div3.p: --Mr. Robt. Wendenburg having purchased on the 1st inst. an interest in my business, the style of the firm will in future be

Thankful for past favors, I beg for a continuance of the same for the new firm.
I embrace this opportunity to ask those of my customers who have not settled their last year's account to make prompt payment to Mr. Wendenburg; and those having claims against me will please present them for payment.
Albert Lybrock.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p: --The "limited partnership" heretofore existing between Thos. Bruce, of Halifax, Va., and J. Pannill, of Richmond, was (in consequence of the death of the former) dissolved on 1st inst.

div3.head: Co-Partnership Notice.
div3.p:
We have this day associated with us Mr. Peter Spilman, as a partner in our business.
The style of the firm, from this day, will be Beers, Poindexter & Co.

All persons indebted to the old firm will please call and settle their accounts as early as possible.
Beers & Poindexter.
Having associated with me, in the Grocery business, my son, Wm. H. Beveridge, the business will be hereafter conducted under the firm of J. W. Beveridge & Son.

I take this method of returning my thanks to my friends and customers for their very liberal patronage they have bestowed on me for the many past years, and hope, by strict attention to business, we may merit a continuance of the same.--All persons indebted to me will confer a great favor by calling and settling their accounts, and all persons having bills against me will please present them for settlement

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p: --The co-partnership heretofore existing between Henry Kayton & H. H. Plaut, has been this day dissolved by mutual consent.
All accounts of the late firm will be collected, and all claims against the same paid, by Mr. Henry Kayton.
The business will be continued, as heretofore by Mr. Henry Kayton.

div3.head: Dissolution of Co-Partnership.
div3.p: --By the death of Alex. Hill the co-partnership heretofore existing under the style of Alex. Hill & Co. is dissolved.

The business will be carried on, for a while, for the purpose of settling it up. All persons having claims against the concern will please present them immediately; and all persons indebted to it are particularly requested to make immediate payment.
All sales will be for cash.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:
--The co-partnership of Jones & Clark is this day dissolved by limitation.
The name of the firm will be used by either partner in closing the concern.
the subscriber will continue the Grocery business at the old stand, where he will be glad to see his old customers.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The concern of Samuel M. Price & Co. is dissolved this say by limitation.
The undersigned will continue the business as heretofore, under the name of Samuel Price & Co., assuming all the liabilities of and settling all debts due to the late concern.

The firm of Austin & Gentry was dissolved by mutual consent on the 1st January, 1862. All persons indebted to the concern, will please call at their old stand and settle at once, as they can be seen there at any time.
And all persons having claims against the concern will please present them at once, as we wish to settle up the business of the concern immediately.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Negroes.--Wanted to hire Negroes, (free or slaves.) Laborers Mechanics and Teamsters, for service on the Peninsula, on the following terms and conditions:
It hired by the month (not less than six months) fifteen dollars per month will be paid for Laborers; with rations, comfortable quarters and Medical attendance free.
If hired by the year one hundred dollars per annum, paid quarterly; with rations, comfortable quarters and Medical attendance free, and usual allowance of clothing.
For Teamsters and Mechanics twenty dollars will be paid; and rations, comfortable quarters and Medical attendance free.
The Government will be responsible for the value of these Negroes, If captured by the enemy or allowed to escape to them, or killed in action.
In all other respects the contract of hire will be subject to and conformable to the Laws of Virginia.
For further particulars apply at the office of Hector Davis. Franklin street, near Wall, from 10 o'clock, A. M. to 4 P. M., until the 18th inst.

div3.head: Headquarters Wise Legion
div3.p:
Special Orders No. 252. Absentees from the companies of the Wise Legion will forthwith rejoin them.
They will proceed to Norfolk via Richmond, and thence to the headquarters of the Legion.
The civil authorities are hereby required to arrest all such as are absent without furiougas, and those falling promptly to return will be forthwith advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Davis, Comd'g W. L.
James H. Pearce,
ja 10--3t* A. A. Adj't Gen'l Wise Legion.

div3.head: Chesterfield county.--attention, Artillery!
div3.p: --The members of my command are hereby ordered to meet me at Battery No. 15, on Tuesday, 14th instant, at A. M. We will be mustered into service on that day. Each man will bring two suits of cloths and two blankets, and a bed tick with him.
div3.closer:
L. M. Burpoot,
ja 8--6t* Capt. of Artillery Chesterfield Co.

div3.head: To young officers, and those who wish to become Expert in Military exercises.
div3.p:
--Mr. Charles Decamp, late Drum Major of the Fourteenth Louisiana Regiment, offers his services to all novices in the military profession as instructor in the use of the short Sword, according to the practice of the French Military schools.
He will also give lessons in the Manual of arms, and tea young drummers according to scientific rules.
He will always be found at his rooms, over the Arcade Saloon, opposite the First Market, from 8 o'clock to H. A. M., and from 5 o'clock, P. M., daily.
